Header:
Clear cell odontogenic carcinoma (CCOC) is a rare and aggressive tumor that typically arises in the mandible. CCOC invades surrounding structures and carries a risk of recurrence and metastasis to regional lymph nodes and distant sites (1). More than 80% of CCOCs exhibit EWSR1 gene rearrangement (1,2). The standard of care is surgical gross total resection with wide margins. For cases where surgical margins are close, adjuvant radiotherapy may be administered to reduce the risk of recurrence.

The image shows a CCOC tissue section stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), which label DNA and RNA in the nucleus (purple), and proteins in the cytoplasm and ECM (pink), respectively. 

References:
1	Wright, J. M. & Vered, M. Update from the 4th Edition of the World Health Organization Classification of Head and Neck Tumours: Odontogenic and Maxillofacial Bone Tumors. Head Neck Pathol 11, 68–77 (2017). https://doi.org/10.1007/s12105-017-0794-1
2	Bilodeau, E. A. et al. Clear cell odontogenic carcinomas show EWSR1 rearrangements: a novel finding and a biological link to salivary clear cell carcinomas. The American journal of surgical pathology 37, 1001–1005 (2013). https://doi.org/10.1097/pas.0b013e31828a6727

Waypoints.Name: RECURRENT CLEAR CELL ODONTOGENIC CARCINOMA
Waypoints.Description: This tissue specimen demonstrates a recurrent CCOC. The image shows different regions in the tissue. Additionally, the edge of the sample shows colored ink, which pathologists use to assess surgical margins. The margins in this tissue section are negative for tumor.

Waypoints.Name: Tumor architecture
Waypoints.Description: The tumor is arranged as nests and cords of tumor cells interspersed between bands of dense collagenous stroma.

Waypoints.Name: Tumor cells
Waypoints.Description: The tumor cells have a polygonal shape with small, round, darkly staining nuclei with minimal pleomorphism, and prominent clear cytoplasm. The nests of tumor cells are surrounded by thick collagen bands, which focally exhibit hyalinization or ossification. Mitotic figures are rare indicative of low proliferative activity, and tumor necrosis is absent.
